The patient is a 56-year-old female with a history of failed kidney transplant on peritoneal dialysis (PD) and low-dose immunosuppression. She presented to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and headache, and was found to have a hypertensive emergency. The patient's symptoms improved after receiving labetalol in the emergency department, which also decreased her heart rate to the low 60s. The medical team wants to discontinue nitroprusside as soon as possible to avoid cyanide toxicity.

The patient has been experiencing dyspnea, which is likely due to worsening pulmonary edema/heart failure with volume overload seen on chest X-ray. She also has a new diagnosis of asthma, which may have been worsening her heart failure all along. The patient is already on lasix and reports missing a few doses because of nausea and vomiting. She endorses chronic cough with lisinopril but no sputum production or fever. Physical examination findings are consistent with heart failure and no right heart strain seen on EKG.

The patient has end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and is on PD. Her nausea and vomiting are likely symptoms of uremia. She also has acid-base metabolic acidosis likely due to renal failure. Urgent PD dialysis is needed today, along with follow-up electrolytes. She should resume prednisone and cellcept, appreciate renal recommendations, and resume renal gel and calcitriol.

The patient has leukocytosis, which may be due to a lung infection. Viral upper respiratory infection (URI) is possible but less likely. Follow-up culture data should be obtained, and antibiotics should be held off for now.

The patient's nausea and vomiting are most likely due to uremia, although post-tussive emesis is also possible. Ruling out acute coronary syndrome (ACS), ondansetron (Zofran) can be given as needed, along with dialysis as mentioned above.

The patient has anemia with a baseline hematocrit (Hct) of ~27 and is on Procrit for anemia of chronic disease. With a positive guaiac test for emesis, concern for upper gastrointestinal (UGI) bleed is present, although hemodynamics do not support hypovolemic instability. Active T+S, PPI daily, and transfusion if Hct <21 or active bleeding are recommended.

The patient's headache has resolved with blood pressure control, and a CT head was negative. Differential diagnosis includes migraine or headache of unknown origin.

The patient's elevated INR is likely nutritional, with no history of liver disease and not on anticoagulation. No signs of bleeding are present. INR should be trended.

ICU care includes ADAT nutrition, glycemic control, lines, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with subcutaneous (SQ) UF heparin, stress ulcer with proton pump inhibitor (PPI), and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) precautions. The patient has full code status and will be staying in the ICU.
